liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Karen Williams, mayor of Redland City Council, is speaking on ABC News about the Russell Island blaze which killed a father and his five sons over the weekend. She says the tragedy will resonate with the community for quite some time. "Which is why Redland City Council spent most of yesterday making sure that we've got the appropriate resources on the island and on the mainland to wrap around the community and those people who are first responders or have been impacted by this tragic event," she says. Disaster chaplains and community support are made available to residents and a space has been set up for people who want to pay their respects or need assistance. Williams says the island, which is home to about 3,500 people, is a very small and tight-knit community. "Everybody knows everybody and, at the same time, they're all there to make sure that they support each other," she says. "I just think they are still reeling at this whole event. It's so tragic."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Queensland's Russell Island community grieving after deadly house fire, mayor says

props.alt: A close up of a woman in a black jacket in her office

children.content: Redland City Council Mayor Karen Williams
(ABC News)
Karen Williams, mayor of Redland City Council, is speaking on ABC News about the
Russell Island blaze
which killed a father and his five sons over the weekend.
She says the tragedy will resonate with the community for quite some time.

"Which is why Redland City Council spent most of yesterday making sure that we've got the appropriate resources on the island and on the mainland to wrap around the community and those people who are first responders or have been impacted by this tragic event," she says.
Disaster chaplains and community support are made available to residents and a space has been set up for people who want to pay their respects or need assistance.
Williams says the island, which is home to about 3,500 people, is a very small and tight-knit community.
"Everybody knows everybody and, at the same time, they're all there to make sure that they support each other," she says.
"I just think they are still reeling at this whole event. It's so tragic."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Syrian state media says an Israeli missile attack on Syria's capital Damascus has killed four soldiers, wounded four more and caused "some material damage". "At about 2:20 in the morning today, the Israeli enemy launched an aerial aggression from the direction of the occupied Syrian Golan Heights, targeting some points in the vicinity of the city of Damascus," a military source reportedly says. Syrian air defences intercepted the Israeli missiles and shot down some of them, the source added. Israel has for years carried out attacks against what it has described as Iran-linked targets in Syria, where Iran's influence has grown since it began supporting President Bashar al-Assad in the civil war that started in 2011. Reporting by Reuters
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Syrian state media says four soldiers have been killed in an Israeli missile attack

children.content: Syrian state media says an Israeli missile attack on Syria's capital Damascus has killed four soldiers, wounded four more and caused "some material damage".

"At about 2:20 in the morning today, the Israeli enemy launched an aerial aggression from the direction of the occupied Syrian Golan Heights, targeting some points in the vicinity of the city of Damascus," a military source reportedly says.
Syrian air defences intercepted the Israeli missiles and shot down some of them, the source added.

Israel has for years carried out attacks against what it has described as Iran-linked targets in Syria, where Iran's influence has grown since it began supporting President Bashar al-Assad in the civil war that started in 2011.
Reporting by Reuters

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The man found guilty of murdering Michelle Bright in 1999 will spend at least 24 years behind bars. Family and friends of the 17-year-old clapped and sighed with relief when Justice Robert Allan Hulme sentenced Craig Rumsby to 32 years ' jail, with a non-parole period of 24 years. The 56-year-old was found guilty by a jury in June of murdering the high school student at Gulgong in the state's central west. You can keep reading this story here:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Craig Rumsby sentenced to 32 years' jail for 1999 murder of NSW teen

featuredLink.title: Man sentenced to 32 years' jail for 1999 murder of teenager Michelle Bright

props.alt: a woman in nineties style hair and clothes smiles at the camera

image.altText: ASX in Sydney

items.synopsis: The ASX is following modest falls on Wall Street on Friday,Â with no major corporate profit results or economic data out today.Â Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.Â

title.children: ASX follows Wall Street lower as US data show wages growth despite employment slowdown

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: As pointed to by the futures market, the ASX has slipped slightly in early trade. Shortly after 11am AEST, the ASX 200 was off 0.2% at 7,311 points. Industrials and health care saw the biggest declines early on, with the big financials and basic materials (mining) sectors also in the red. Real, estate, utilities and energy were helping to prop the benchmark share index up from bigger falls. Biggest declines on ASX 200: Block: -10.6% to $97.88 Lake Resources: -7% to $0.20 Resmed: -3.7% to $29.58 Nanosonics: -3.1% to $4.64 Virgin Money: -3.1% to $3.40 Biggest gains on ASX 200: De Grey Mining: +4.1% to $1.39 Pilbara Minerals: +3.4% to $5.16 Allkem: +3.4% to $14.85 Bellevue Gold: +3.2% to $1.5275 Lynas Rare Earths: +2.2% to $6.835
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX posts modest losses in early trade

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The US non-farm payrolls numbers were the major economic news on Friday, and moved both share and bond markets. The Bureau of Labor Statistics reported that 187,000 jobs were added to the US economy in July. That might sound like a lot, but it's pretty small in a country with around 335 million people. Combined with a downwardly revised jobs gain in June, which was even smaller, it is the weakest jobs growth in two and a half years. Economists were generally expecting around 200,000 jobs to be created. Despite the fall in jobs, unemployment fell from 3.6 to 3.5% and wages growth continued at an annual pace of 4.4% â down from recent peaks around 5%, but above expectations. "US Treasuries [bond prices] rallied immediately following the non-farm payroll headlines, from 4.20% to 4.10% in the first 90 minutes, and to below 4.05% during the afternoon to end the week at 4.034%, a fall of just 8bps on the week," wrote NAB's Ray Attrill. "The 2yr [yield] slumped from 4.945% quickly down to 4.80% with falls extended to 4.764% by the close to be 12bps down on the week. Pricing for a further 25bps Fed rate hike in September reduced from 17% to 13% ." However, Westpac's Imre Speizer said the data was not a major shock to the Federal Reserve's Open Market Committee (which sets US central bank interest rates). "FOMC member Goolsbee said the jobs report was 'pretty much what we expected', the labour market cooling a little but still 'extremely strong'. He was not concerned about the sticky wage data, stressing wages are a backward looking indicator," Speizer observed.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: US employment growth slows, but wages growth remains strong

children.content: The US non-farm payrolls numbers were the major economic news on Friday, and moved both share and bond markets.
The
Bureau of Labor Statistics
reported that
187,000 jobs were added to the US economy in July
That might sound like a lot, but it's pretty small in a country with around 335 million people.
Combined with a downwardly revised jobs gain in June, which was even smaller, it is the
weakest jobs growth in two and a half years
Economists were generally expecting around 200,000 jobs to be created.
Despite the fall in jobs,
Â
unemployment fell from 3.6 to 3.5%
and
wages growth continued at an annual pace of 4.4%
â down from recent peaks around 5%, but above expectations.

"US Treasuries [bond prices] rallied immediately following the non-farm payroll headlines, from 4.20% to 4.10% in the first 90 minutes, and to below 4.05% during the afternoon to end the week at 4.034%, a fall of just 8bps on the week," wrote NAB's Ray Attrill.
"The 2yr [yield] slumped from 4.945% quickly down to 4.80% with falls extended to 4.764% by the close to be 12bps down on the week.
Pricing for a further 25bps Fed rate hike in September reduced from 17% to 13%
However,
Westpac's Imre Speizer
said the data was not a major shock to the Federal Reserve's Open Market Committee (which sets US central bank interest rates).

"FOMC member Goolsbee said the jobs report was 'pretty much what we expected', the labour market cooling a little but still 'extremely strong'. He was not concerned about the sticky wage data, stressing wages are a backward looking indicator," Speizer observed.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Good morning, I'll be taking you through all of today's market action, hopefully with a couple of guest posts from Rachel Pupazzoni who's on the ground in Kalgoorlie for the annual Diggers and Dealers mining conference. There's likely to be more action there than on the ASX, where the futures are pointing to just a 0.2% decline at the open after Wall Street eased on Friday. Jobs data were the major driver for US stocks at the end of last week, coming in a bit weaker than expected although wages growth remained slightly higher (more on that in a few minutes). Locally, while reporting season ramps up this week, that is not today, with no major firms releasing profit results. In a post soon, I'll flag the main ones to look out for later this week. While there's not a lot of big news about, there's still plenty to talk about, so let's dive in.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX set to edge lower on signs of emerging US jobs weakness
